title: Want clarificaton on Primary Password encryption
content:
I see this question was asked before (https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1415951) but the thread is now archived and I don't think the concern of the poster was understood/answered.

Your Thunderbird profile contains all the credentials needed to "be you" by having full access to all linked email accounts. In order to protect these accounts a Private Password can be created. It prevents someone trying to use Thunderbird as you (using your profile) from seeing the passwords or establishing connections to the email servers.

The question I have (and I believe was being asked) is, does using a Private Password actually encrypt the account credentials, or does it just block someone when they're using the Thunderbird program? Asked another way, would a bad actor with access to the profile and access to appropriate sleuthing tools be able to recover the credentials--from the files alone--thus bypassing the private password of the Thunderbird program?
creator: chull_56

title: Email Sent folders
content:
I am using Tbird 115.16.0esr (64 bit) on Linux Mint 20.2 desktop and until recently my outgoing Tbird emails displayed in a Folder called ‘Sent Mail’.

Currently my Tbird “start page” shows Folders for both ‘Sent’ and ‘Sent Mail’

But Tbird Account Settings > Copies & Folders> shows only “Sent folder on” – my email account name and does not offer a ‘Sent Mail folder on’. 

However my Gmail account, when viewed via browser, shows only ‘Sent’.

Now my outgoing emails it show up in both ‘Sent’ and ‘Sent Mail’ folders.

I would like to retain the previous ‘Sent Mail’ as the operative folder on Tbird “start page”. How do I go about that since “Sent Mail” isn’t offered in Tbird account settings and “Sent Mail” doesn’t show in Gmail (although all outgoing emails seem to show in gmail’s ‘Sent’ folder) ?

Martin B.

title: Unable to write the email to the inbox
content:
Hello In my Thunderbird (Windows 10), undated to last release, I have several mailboxes. For one mailbox (and only this) I am getting error messages like these:

"Unable to write the email to the mailbox. Make sure the file system allows you write privileges, and you have enough disk space to copy the mailbox." and "The folder ‘Inbox on .......' could not be compacted because writing to folder failed. Verify that you have enough disk space, and that you have write privileges to the file system

I have deactivated the relevant functions on antivirus software (Kaspersky) and still get the error. I have also tried to start in restricted mode, still the same message.

Any suggestion? best regards Bertin

title: Making multiple Mbox files look like one virtual folder
content:
The problem with standard email storage methods is that they don't scale well. Mbox, the default in Thunderbird, creates large files, and if you backup changed files, every backup requires recopying a multi-gigabyte file, because it has changed when even one message was added or deleted. Maildir, the alternative, puts each message in a separate file. But file systems have a lot of overhead and their own limits. When you have hundreds of thousands of messages, especially on a PC, that clutters the computer's file system, and between the file cluster size and directory overhead, it wastes a lot of space and slows down other operations. Two bad options. And let's not be too snarky about what that company from Redmond does in its awful mail system, with a giant proprietary mail database file that sometimes gets corrupted...

It is obviously a lot to ask to create a new mail file format that scales better. It would not be standard and could break some things anyway, though in the long run it might be a good idea. But I have an idea that might work for Thunderbird. As it stands now, it is possible to create archive files by month or year. Then new mail doesn't require those to be re-copied. WHAT IF a "virtual mailbox" could be created that, instead of consisting of one Mbox file or one maildir directory, consisted of a set of Mbox files treated by the UI as one? Quick Filter would filter them all as one, unlike with archives, and you could scroll through them all and sort them and see threads, but they'd be stored as monthly or annual (or whatever) files, the way archives are. Sending and receiving would be unchanged, using the current folders, but periodically the folder could have the oldest ones moved out and still made part of a virtual folder.

There are some modest virtual folder capabilities now, but I don't see how to do this. Does it seem like a possibility with what's there, or a modest enhancement, or is that the kind of thing that would be a huge effort?
creator: fred37

title: Thunderbird 128.6.0esr(64-bitar) works in Win10 but problem in Win11
content:
Hello, I have problems to use Thunderbird client in my Win11 laptop. In late 2023 windows introduced modern authentication and after that I have big problems to have just any mail client to work. I used to use Outlook classic but that one failed I stared to test different clients e.g. Thunderbird, Mailbird, emclient but with no luck! My feeling is that it has to do with my Windows 11 installation. The process always fails when trying to log in to the IMAP server. When googeling around my impression is the Thunderbird should do it - but sadly not in my laptop.

I decided to dive into the details and try to find why it fails, so please see below analyse.

Regards Stefan

Problem description: Thunderbird 128.6.0esr(64-bitar) works in Windows 10 environment but same thunderbird version fails to log in to IMAP-server in windows 11.

Analyze logging created using .bat file with: set MOZ_LOG=IMAP:5,timestamp 

       set MOZ_LOG_FILE=%USERPROFILE%\Desktop\imaplog       "%ProgramFiles%\Mozilla Thunderbird\thunderbird.exe"

Observation: Windows 10 where login works: 2108499af00:imap.privat.bahnhof.se:NA:ProcessCurrentURL:imap://mb111111@imap.privat.bahnhof.se:993/select%3E.INBOX: = currentUrl

Windows 11 where login fails: 243f98e5900:imap.privat.bahnhof.se:NA:ProcessCurrentURL:imap://mb111111@imap.privat.bahnhof.se:993/select%3E%5EINBOX: = currentUrl %3E = ”>” %5E = ”^”

It looks like the dot (.) has been incorrectly coded. Is this difference the problem and is it connected to windows 11 or?

title: How to send encrypted emails - how to obtain the keys from signed emails
content:
I ask a person to send me a signed email so that i can send them an encrypted email. How is this process supposed to work in thunderbird? I receive a signed email, what next? Clearly, thunderbird sees the signature but does not add the public key to the contact. This is in contradiction with [page] that states: The standard way of distributing a person's certificate is to send a digitally signed email. If you have received a signed email from your correspondent, click the email to view it. If Thunderbird considers the email's signature and the sender's certificate valid, it will automatically be imported and available when you attempt to encrypt an email to that correspondent using the S/MIME technology. If you don't have a signed email from your correspondent yet, you could ask them to send a digitally signed email to you.

Note that certificates issued by CAs may have a short validity period. Certificates are no longer usable after the validity period has expired. In that case your correspondent will have to obtain a new certificate. Once that happened they will be able to send you a new digitally signed email with a valid certificate.

Organizations that operate an LDAP server may configure their server to store S/MIME certificates. If an LDAP server is configured, Thunderbird may automatically query the LDAP server if it needs to obtain a S/MIME certificate.

To review the list of S/MIME certificates that you already have, you can use Thunderbird's Certificate Manager.

The certificate shows that it is valid, yet, clicking reply gives "key issues" which shows no key available. Similarly, if I sign an email with pgp key and send it, thunderbird sees that it is signed but tells me that i need to obtain public pgp key. So it seems that signatures and encryption are completely unusable.
creator: leosenko

title: Labels
content:
I have two problems with labels after changing computer. The first is that by entering the names of the labels, they are put in alphabetical order and not in the previous one. After years of use, it’s quite annoying...

The second is that in the grouping of messages by labels, they are doubled. Instead in the Inbox folder no. And this is more serious.

MacBook Pro M4 Pro, macOS 15.2 Thunderbird 128.6.0esr (64 bit)

Ho due problemi con le etichette dopo aver cambiato computer. Il primo è che inserendo i nomi delle etichette, queste vengono messe in ordine alfabetico e non in quello precedente. Dopo anni di utilizzo la cosa è piuttosto scocciante...

Il secondo è che nel raggruppamento dei messaggi per etichette, questi vengono raddoppiati. Invece nella cartella Posta in Arrivo no. E questo è più grave.
creator: bertofa

title: Trying to connect to GoDaddy Outlook account
content:
Hi —

I'm trying to connect to my GoDaddy hosted Outlook email account without much luck.

I have the configuration I need from them, which I've tried in Thunderbird; however, it's not working. Could you please advise whether the requests are making it through to you and, if so, what I'm doing wrong?

I've attached my configuration.

I would really appreciate any help.

Alex :)
creator: alexandersimonjones
